sp.l: Thoſe are unſeemly: move one can ſerve ye
Can honour ye, can love ye.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: 'Pray ye tell quickly
He will return and then

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: I'le tell ye inſtantly
Move me, and I wil move any way to ſerve ye
Move your heart this way (Lady)

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: 'Pray ye heare me.
Behold the ſport of Love, when he is imperious
Behold the ſlave of Love

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Move my Queen this way?
Sure, he's ſome worthy man: then if he hedge me
Or here to open him.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: Do but behold me
If there be pity in you, do but view me,
But view the miſery I have undertaken
For you the povertie.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: He will come preſently.
Now play your beſt Sir, though I looſe this Rook here
Yet I get Libertie.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: I'le ſeize your fair hand
And warm it with a hundred, hundred kiſſes
The God of love warm your deſires but equal
That ſhall play my game now.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What do you mean Sir?
Why do you ſtop me?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: That ye may intend me.
The time ha's bleſt us both: Love bids us uſe it.
I am a Gentleman nobly deſcended:
Young to invite your Love, rich to maintain it.
I bring a whole heart to ye, thus I give it,
And to thoſe burning altars thus I offer,
And thus divine lips, where perpetuall Sping grows.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Take that, ye are too ſaucy.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: How proud Lady?
Strike my deſerts?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I was too blame.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What wiſe, there?
Heaven keep my houſe from thieves.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: I am wretched:
Opened, diſcovered, loſt to my wiſhes.
I ſhall be whooted at.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What noiſe was this (wife?)
Why doſt thou ſmile?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: This proud thing will betray me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why theſe lie here? what anger (deare?)

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Why none, Sir,
Onely a chance, your pupill ſaid he plaid well,
And ſo indeed he do's: he undertook for ye
Becauſe I would not ſit ſo long time idle
I made my Liberty avoided your mate,
And he again as cunningly endangered me,
Indeed he put me ſtrangely to it. When preſently
Hearing you come, and having broke his ambuſh too
Having the ſecond time brought off my Queen fair,
I roſe o'th' ſudden ſmilingly to ſhew ye,
My apron caught the Cheſſe-board, and the men,
And there the noiſe was.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thou art grown a Maſter,
For all this, I ſhall beat ye.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: Or I, Lawyer,
For now I love her more, 'twas a neat anſwer,
And by it hangs a mighty hope, I thank her
She gave my pate a ſound knock that it rings yet,
But you ſhall have a ſounder if I live Lawyer,
My heart akes yet I would not be in that fear—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am glad ye are a gameſter, Sir, ſometimes
For recreation we two ſhall fight hard at it.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: He will prove too hard for me,

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: I hope he ſhall do,
But your Ches-board is too hard for my head, line that good Lady,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I have been attoning two moſt wrangling neighbours,
They had no money, therefore I made even
Come, let's go in, and eat, truly I am hungry.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I have eaten already, I muſt intreat your pardon

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do as ye pleaſe, we ſhall expect ye at ſupper.
He ha's got a little heart, now it ſeems handſomly,

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You'l get no little head, if I do not look to ye.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: If ever I do catch thee again thou vanity—

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I was too blame to be ſo raſh, I am ſorie— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Heare but my reaſons,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O my patience heare 'em.
Can cunning falſhood colour an excuſe?
With any ſeeming ſhape of borrowed truth?
Extenuate this wofull wrong, not error.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: You gave conſent that to defeat my brother
I ſhould take any courſe,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But not to make
The cure more loathſome then the fowle diſeaſe:
Was't not enough you took me to your bed,
Tir'd with looſe dalliance, and with emptie veines,
All thoſe abilities ſpent before and waſted,
That could conferre the name of mother on me?
But that (to perfect my account of ſorrow)
For my long barrenneſſe you muſt highten it
By ſhewing to my face, that you were fruitfull
Hug'd in the baſe embraces of another?
If Solitude that dwelt beneath my roofe,
And want of children was a torment to me
What end of my vexation to behold
A baſtard to upbraid me with my wants?
And heare the name of father paid to ye
Yet know my ſelf no mother,
What can I ſay?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: ſhall I confeſſe my fault and ask your pardon?
Will that content ye?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: If it could make void,
What is confirm'd in Court No, no, Don Henrique
You ſhall know that I find my ſelf abus'd,
And adde to that I have a womans anger,
And while I look upon this Baſilisk
Whoſe envious eyes hath blaſted all my comforts
Reſt confident I'le ſtudy my dark ends,
And not your pleaſures,

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: Noble Lady, heare me,
Not as my Fathers ſon, but as your ſervant,
Vouchſafe to heare me, for ſuch in my duty,
I ever will appeare: And far be it from
My poore ambition, ever to looke on you,
But with that reverence; which a ſlave ſtands bound
To pay a worthy Miſtris: I have heard
That Dames of higheſt place, nay Queenes themſelves,
Diſdaine not to be ſerv'd by ſuch as are
Of meaneſt Birth: and I ſhall be moſt happie,
To be emploi'd when you pleaſe to command me
Even in the courſeſt Office, as your Page,
I can wayte on your trencher:: fill your wine
Carry your pontafles, and be ſometimes bleſs'd
In all humilitie to touch your feete
Or if that you eſteeme that too much grace
I can run by your Coach: obſerve your lookes
And hope to gaine a fortune by my ſervice,
With your good favour, which now, as a Son,
I dare not challenge

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: As a Son,

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: Forgive me
I will forget the name, let it be death
For me to call you Mother.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Still upbraided?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: No way left to appeaſe you?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: None: now heare me,
Heare what I vow before the face of heaven,
And if I breake it all plagues in this life,
And thoſe that after death are fear'd, fall on me,
While that this Baſtard ſtaies under my rooffe,
Looke for no peace at home, for I renounce
All Offices of a wife,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: What am I falne to?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I will not eate, nor ſleepe with you and thoſe howres
Which I ſhould ſpend in prayers for your health
Shall be emploi'd in Curſes,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Terrible.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: All the day long, i'le be as tedious to you
As lingring fevers, and i'le watch the nights,
To ring alon'd your ſhame and breake your ſleepes
Or if you doe but ſlumber, i'le appeare
In the ſhape of all my wrongs, and like a fury
Fright you to madnes, and if all this faile
To worke out my revenge, I have friends and kinſmen,
That will not ſit downe tame with the diſgrace
That's offer'd to our noble familie
In what I ſuffer,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: How am I devided
Betweene the duties I owe as a Husband,
And pietie of a Parent?

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: I am taught Sir
By the inſtinct of nature that obedience
Which bids me to prefer your peace of mind,
Before thoſe pleaſures that are deareſt to me
Be wholy hers (my Lord) I quit all parts,
That I may challenge: may you grow old together
And no diſtaſt e're find you and before
The Characters of age are printed on you
May you ſee many Images of your ſelves,
Though I, like ſome falſe Glaſſe, that's never look'd in
Am caſt a ſide, and broken from this hower
(Unles invited, which I dare not hope for)
I never will ſet my forbidden feete,
Over your threſhold: onely give me leave
Though caſt off to the world, to mention you,
In my devotions 'tis all I ſue for
And ſo I take my laſt leave

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Though I am
Devoted to a wife nay allmoſt ſol'd
A ſlave to ſerve her pleaſures, yet I cannot
So part with all humanity, but I muſt
Shew ſomething of a Father: thou ſhalt not goe
Unfurniſh'd and unfriended too: take that
To guard thee from neceſſities; may thy goodnes
Meet many favours, and thine innocence
Deſerve to be the heire of greater fortunes,
Then thou wer't borne to. Scorne me not Violante
This baniſhment is a kind of civill death,
And now, as it were at his Funerall
To ſhed a teare or two, is not unmanly
And ſo farewell for ever: one word more,
Though I muſt never ſee thee (my Aſcanio)
When this is ſpent (for ſo the Judge decreed)
Send to me for ſupply: are you pleas'd now?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Yes: I have cauſe: to ſee you howle and blubber
At the parting of my torment, & your ſhame Bed ready, wine, table Standiſh & Paper.
'Tis well: proceed: ſupply his wants: doe doe:
Let the great dowre I brought ſerve to maintain
Your Baſtards riots: ſend my Clothes and Jewells,
To your old acquaintance, your deare dame his Mother
Now you begin to melt, I know 'twill follow,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Is all I doe miſconſtrude?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I will take
A courſe to right my ſelfe a ſpeeding one:
By the bleſſ'd Saints, I will; if I prove cruell
The ſhame to ſee thy fooliſh pitty taught me
To looſe my naturall ſoftnes, keepe off from me
Thy flateries are infectious, and i'le fle thee
As I would doe a Leaper.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Let not fury
Tranſport you ſo: you know I am your Creature,
All love, but to your ſelf, with him, hath left me
I'le ioyne with you in any thing

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: In vaine
I'le take mine owne waies, and will have no partners,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I will not croſſe you,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Doe not, they ſhall find
That to a Woman of her hopes beguil'd
A viper troad on, or an Aſpick's, mild. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Sits the game there? I have you by mine order,
I love Leandro for't

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: But you muſt ſhew it
In lending him your helpe, to gain him meanes
And opportunitie.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He ſhall want nothing,
I know my Advocate to a hayre, and what
Will fetch him from his prayers, if he uſe any,
I am honyed with the project: I would have him horn'd
For a moſt pretious Beaſt.

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: But you looſe time;

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I am gon, inſtruct you Diego, you will find him
A ſharpe and ſubtle knave, give him but hints
And he will amplifie: Se all things ready
I'll fetch him with a vengeance.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: If he faile now,
Wee'll give him over too,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Tuſh he is fleſh'd,
And knowes what vaine to ſtrike for his owne credit.

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: All things are ready.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Then we ſhall have a merry Scene, no're feare it.

div.head: Scena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Amaranta (with a note) and Moore.

sp.speaker: Amar.
sp.l: Is thy Maſter gone out?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Even now, the Curat fetch'd him,
About a ſerious buſineſſe as it ſeem'd,
For he ſnatch'd up his Cloak, and bruſh'd his hat ſtrait,
Set his Band handſomely, and out he gallop'd.

sp.speaker: Amar.
sp.l: 'Tis well, 'tis very well, he went out (Egla.)
As luckily, as one would ſay, goe Husband,
He was call'd by providence: fling this ſhort paper
Into Leandro's Cell, and waken him,
He is monſtrous vexed, and muſty, at my Cheſſe-play;
But this ſhall ſupple him, when he has read it:
Take your owne recreation for two houres,
And hinder nothing.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: If I doe, I'll hang for't. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If that you lov'd Aſcanio for himſelfe,
And not your private ends, you rather ſhould
Bleſſe the faire opportunitie, that reſtores him
To his Birth-right, and the Honours he was borne to,
Then grieve at his good Fortune.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Grieve Octavio?
I would reſigne my Eſſence, that he were
As happy as my love could faſhion him,
Though every bleſſing that ſhould fall on him,
Might prove a curſe to me, my ſorrow ſprings
Out of my feare, and doubt he is not ſafe.
I am acquainted with Don Henrique's nature,
And I have heard too much the fiery temper
Of Madam Violante: can you thinke
That ſhe, that almoſt is at war with heaven
For being barren, will with equall eyes
Behold a Son of mine?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: His Fathers care,
That for the want of Iſſue tooke him home,
(Though with the forfeiture of his owne fame)
Will looke unto his ſafetie.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Step-mothers
Have many eyes, to find a way to miſchiefe,
Though blind to goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Here comes Don Jamy,
And with him our Aſcanio.

sp.speaker: Jamy.
sp.l: Good youth leave me,
I know thou art forbid my company,
And onely to be ſeene with me, will call on
Thy Fathers anger.

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: Sir if that to ſerve you
Could looſe me any thing (as indeed it cannot)
I ſtill would follow you. Alas I was borne
To doe you hurt but not to help my ſelfe,
I was, for ſome particular end, tooke home,
But am caſt off againe.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Is't poſſible?

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: The Lady, whom my Father calls his wife
Abhors my ſight, is ſick of me, and forc'd him
To turne me out of dores.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: By my beſt hopes
I thanke her crueltie, for it comes neere
A ſaving charitie.

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: I am onely happy
That yet I can relieve you, 'pray you ſhare:
My Father's wondrous kind, and promiſes
That I ſhould be ſupplide: but ſure the Lady
Is a malitious woman, and I feare
Meanes me no good.

sp.speaker: Iamy.
sp.l: I am turn'd a ſtone with wonder,
And know not what to thinke.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: From my Lady,
Your private eare and this—

sp.speaker: Iamy.
sp.l: New Miracles?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: She ſayes, if you dare make your ſelfe a Fortune,
She will propoſe the meanes; My Lord Don Henrique
Is now from home and ſhe alone expects you,
If you dare truſt her ſo, if not deſpaire of
A ſecond offer, Exit.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Though there were an Ambuſh
Layd for my life, I,ll on and ſound this ſecret,
Retire thee (my Aſcanio) with thy Mother:
But ſtir not forth, ſome great deſigne's on foot,
Fall what can fall, if e're the Sun be ſet,
I ſee you not, give me dead.

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: We will expect you,
And thoſe bleſs'd Angels, that love goodneſſe, guard you.

div.head: Scena Quinta.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Is't poſſible he ſhould be rich?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Moſt poſſible,
He hath bin long, though he had but little gettings,
Drawing together, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Accounted a poore Sexton,
Honeſt poore Diego,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I aſſure ye, a cloſe Fellow,
Both cloſe, and ſcraping, and that fills the bags, Sir,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A notable good Fellow too?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Sometimes, Sir, Diego ready in Bed, wine, cup.
When he hop'd to drink a man into a ſurfeit,
That he might gaine by his Grave.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So many thouſands?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Heaven knowes what.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange,
Tis very ſtrange; but we ſee by endeavour,
And honeſt labour—

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Milo by continuance
Grew from a ſilly Calfe (with your worſhips reverence)
To carry a Bull, from a penny, to a pound, Sir,
And from a pound, to many: 'tis the progreſſe.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ye ſay true, but he lov'd to feed well alſo,
And that me-thinks—

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: From another mans Trencher, Sir,
And there he found it ſeaſon'd with ſmall charge:
There he would play the Tyrant, and would devoure ye
More then the Graves he made, at home he liv'd
Like a Camelion ſuckt th'Ayre of miſery, Table out Stan|diſh paper, ſtools.
And grew fat by th'Brewis of an Eg-ſhel,
Would ſmell a Cooks ſhop, and goe home and ſurfeit,
And be a moneth in faſting out that Fever.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Theſe are good Symptomes: do's he lye ſo ſick ſay ye?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Oh, very ſick.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And choſen me Executor?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Onely your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No hope of his amendment?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: None, that we find.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He hath no kinſmen neither?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: 'Truth, very few.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: His mind will be the quieter,
What Doctors has he?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: There's none ſir he believes in.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They are but needleſſe things, in ſuch extremities.
Who drawes the good-man's will?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Marry that doe I, Sir.
And to my griefe.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Griefe will doe little now, Sir,
Draw it to your comfort, Friend, and as I counſell ye,
An honeſt man, but ſuch men live not alwayes
Who are about him?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Many now he is paſſing,
That would pretend to his love, yes, and ſome gentlemen
That would faine counſell him, and be of his kindred;
Rich men can want no heires, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They doe ill,
Indeed they doe, to trouble him: very ill, Sir,
But we ſhall take a care.

div.stage: Enter Diego (in a Bed) Millanes, Arſenio, and Pariſhioners.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Will ye come neare, Sir,
'Pray ye bring him out; Now ye may ſee in what ſtate:
Give him freſh ayre. Bed thruſt out.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am ſorry, Neighbour Diego,
To find ye in ſo weake a ſtate.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Ye are welcome,
But I am fleeting, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Me-thinkes he looks well,
His colour freſh, and ſtrong, his eyes are chearfull.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A glimmering before death, 'tis nothing els Sir,
Do you ſee how he fumbles with the ſheet? do ye note that

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: My learned Sir 'pray ye ſit: I am bold to ſend for ye,
To take a care of what I leave.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Doe you heare that?

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: Play the knave finely.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: So I will, I warrant ye,
And carefully.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'Pray ye doe not trouble him,
You ſee he's weake and has a wandring fancie.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: My honeſt Neighbours, weep not, I muſt leave ye,
I cannot alwayes beare ye company,
VVe muſt drop ſtill, there is no remedie:
'Pray ye Maſter Curat, will ye write my Teſtament,
And write it largely it may be remembred
And be witneſſe to my Legacies good Gentlemen;
Your worſhip I doe make my full Executor,
You are a man of wit and underſtanding:
Give me a cup of wine to raiſe my Spirits,
For I ſpeake low: I wou●d before theſe Neighbours
Have ye to ſweare (Sir) that you will ſee it executed,
And what I give, let equally be rendred
For my ſoules health.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I vow it truly, Neighbours,
Let not that trouble ye before all theſe,
Once more I give my Oath.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Then ſet me higher,
And pray ye come neare me all.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: VVe are ready for ye.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Now ſpur the Aſſe, and get our friend time.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Firſt then,
After I have given my Body to the wormes
(For they muſt be ſerv'd firſt, they are ſeldome cozen'd)

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Remember your Pariſh, Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Y u ſpeake truly,
I doe remember it, a lewd vile Pariſh,
And pray it may be mended: To the Poore of it,
(VVhich is to all the Pariſh) I give nothing,
For nothing, unto nothing, is moſt naturall,
Yet leave as much ſpace, as will build an Hoſpitall,
Their children may pray for me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What doe you give to it?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Set downe two thouſand Duckets,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'Tis a good gift,
And will be long remembred.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: To your worſhip,
(Becauſe you muſt take paines to ſee all finiſh'd)
I give two thouſand more, it may be three, Sir,
A poore gratuitie for your paines-taking.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Theſe are large ſummes;

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Nothing to him that has 'em.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: To my old Maſter Vicar, I give five hundred,
(Five hundred, and five hundred, are too few Sir)
But there be more to ſerve.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: This fellow coynes ſure.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Give me ſome more drink. Pray ye buy Books, buy Books,
You have a learned head, ſtuffe it with Libraries,
And underſtand 'em, when ye have done, 'tis Juſtice,
Run not the Pariſh mad with Controverſies,
Nor preach not Abſtinence to longing women,
'Twill budge the bottoms of their conſciences:
I would give the Church new Organs, but I prophecie
The Church-wardens would quickly pipe'em out o'th'Pariſh,
Two hundred Duckets more to mend the chancel,
And to paint true Orthographie, as many,
They write Sunt with a C, which is abominable,
'Pray you ſet that downe, to poore Maidens marriages.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I that's wel thought of, what's your wil in that point?
A meritorious thing.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No end of this will?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: I give per annum two hundred ells of Lockram,
That there be no ſtrait dealings in their Linnens,
But the Sayles cut according to their Burthens;
To all Bell-Ringers, I bequeath new Ropes,
And let them uſe 'em at their owne diſcretions.

sp.speaker: Arſ
sp.l: You may remember us.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: I doe, good Gentlemen,
And I bequeath ye both good carefull Surgeons
A Legacy, you have need of, more then money,
I know you want good Diets and good Lotions,
And in your pleaſures good take heed.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He raves now.
But 'twill be quickly off,

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: I doe bequeath ye
Commodities of pins: browne papers: pack-threds,
Roſt porke & puddings: Ginger-bread, & Jewes-trumps,
Of penny Pipes, and mouldy Pepper: take 'em,
Take 'em even where you pleaſe, and be cozen'd with 'em,
I ſhould bequeath ye Executions alſo,
But thoſe I'll leave to th'Law.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Now he growes temperate.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You will give no more?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: I am loth to give more from ye,
Becauſe I know you will have a care to execute
Onely, to pious uſes, Sir, a little.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: If he be worth all theſe, I am made for ever,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I give to fatall Dames, that ſpin mens threds out,
And poore diſtreſſed Damſells, that are militant
As members of our owne Afflictions,
A hundred Crowns to buy warm tubbs to worke in,
I give five hundred pounds to buy a Church-yard,
A ſpacious Church-yard, to lay Theeves and knaves in,
Rich men, and honeſt men, take all the roome up.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Are ye not weary?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Never of well-doing.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Theſe are mad Legacies.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: They were got as madly;
My Sheep, and Oxen, and my moveables,
My Plate, and Jewells, and five hundred Acres;
I have no heires.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: This cannot be, 'tis Monſtrous.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Three Ships at Sea too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You have made me full Executor.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Full, full, and totall, would I had more to give ye
But theſe may ſerve an honeſt mind.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ye ſay true,
A very honeſt mind, and make it rich too;
Rich, wondrous rich, but where ſhall I raiſe theſe monys,
About your houſe? I ſee no ſuch great promiſes;
Where ſhall I find theſe ſummes?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Even where you pleaſe Sir,
You are wiſe and provident and know buſineſſe
Ev'n raiſe 'em where you ſhal think good, I am reaſonable

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thinke good? will that raiſe thouſands?
What doe you make me?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: You have ſworn to ſee it done, that's all my comfort.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Where I pleaſe? this is pack'd ſure to diſgrace me.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Ye are juſt and honeſt, and I know you will doe it,
Ev'n where you pleaſe, for you know where the wealth is.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am abuſed, betrayed, I am laugh'd at, ſcorn'd,
Baffel'd, and boared, it ſeemes.

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: No, no, ye are fooled.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Moſt finely fooled, and handſomely, and neatly,
Such cunning Maſters muſt be fooled ſometimes, Sir,
And have their worſhips noſes wiped, 'tis healthfull,
We are but quit: you foole us of our moneys
In every Cauſe, in every Quiddit wipe us.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha ha, ſome more drink, for my heart, Gentlemen,
This merry Lawyer— ha, ha, ha, ha this Scholler—
I thinke this fitt will cure me: this Executor—
I ſhall laugh out my Lungs.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: This is deriſion above ſufferance, villany
Plotted, and ſet againſt me.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Faith 'tis knavery,
In troth I muſt confeſſe, thou art fooled indeed, Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Did you thinke, had this man been rich —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'Tis well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: He would have choſen ſuch a Wolfe, a Cancker,
A Maggot-pate, to be his whole Executor.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A Lawyer, that entangles all mens honeſties,
And lives like a Spider in a Cobweb lurking,
And catching at all Flies, that paſſe his pitt-falls?
Puts powder to all States, to make em caper?
Would he truſt you?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Doe you deſerve? I find, Gentlemen,
This Cataplaſme of a well cozen'd Lawyer
Laid to my ſtomach lenifies my Fever,
Me-thinkes I could eat now and walke a little.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am aſham'd to feele how flat I am cheated,
How groſſely, and malitiouſly made a May-game,
A damned Trick; my wife, my wife, ſome Raſcall:
My credit, and my wife, ſome luſtfull villaine,
Some Bawd, ſome Rogue,

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: Some craftie Foole has found ye:
This 'tis Sir, to teach ye to be too buſie,
To covet all the gaines, and all the rumours
To have a ſtirring oare, in all mens actions.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: We did this, but to vex your fine officiouſneſſe.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Good 'yeild ye and go'd thank ye: I am fooled, gentlemen;
The Lawyer is an Aſſe, I doe confeſſe it,
A weak dull ſhallow Aſſe: good even to your worſhips:
Vicar, remember Vicar, Raſcall remember,
Thou notable rich Raſcall.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I doe remember, Sir,
'Pray ye ſtay a little, I have ev'n two Legacies
To make your mouth up, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Remember Varletts,
Quake & remember, Rogues; I have brine for your Buttocks. Ex.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Oh how he frets, and fumes now like a dunghill.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: His gall containes fine ſtuffe now to make poyſons,
Rare damned ſtuffe.

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: Let's after him, and ſtill vex him,
And take my Friend off: by this time he has proſper'd,
He cannot looſe this deere time: 'tis impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Well Diego, thou haſt done.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Haſt done it daintily.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: And ſhalt be as well paid, Boy—

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: Goe, let's crucifie him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I have told ye all my ſtory, and how deſperately.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I doe believe: let's walke on, time is pretious,
Not to be ſpent in words, here no more wooing,
The open Ayre's an enemy to Lovers, Pewter ready for noyſe.
Doe as I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I'll doe any thing,
I am ſo over-joy'd, I'll fly to ſerve ye.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Take your joy moderately, as it is miniſtred,
And as the cauſe invites: that man's a foole
That at the ſight o'th' Bond, dances and leapes,
Then is the true joy, when the money comes.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: You cannot now deny me.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Nay, you know not,
Women have crotchets, and ſtrange fits.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: You ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Hold ye to that and ſweare it confidently,
Then I ſhall make a ſcruple to deny ye:
'Pray ye let's ſtep in, and ſee a friend of mine,
The weather's ſharp: we'll ſtay but halfe an houre,
We may be miſs'd els: a private fine houſe 'tis, Sir,
And we may find many good welcomes.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: Doe Lady,
Doe happy Lady.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: All your mind's of doing,
You muſt be modeſter.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I will be any thing. — Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Open the dores, and give me roome to chafe in
Mine owne roome, and my liberty: why Maid there,
Open, I ſay, and doe not anger me,
I am ſubject to much fury: when ye diſh-clout?
When doe ye come? a ſleepe, ye lazie hell-hound?
Nothing intended, but your eaſe, and eating?
No body here? why wife, why wife? why jewell?
No tongue to anſwer me? 'pre'thee (good Pupill)
Diſpence a little with thy carefull ſtudy,
And ſtep to th' doore, and let me in; nor he neither?
Ha! not at's ſtudy? nor aſleepe? nor no-body?
I'll make ye heare: the houſe of Ignorance,
No ſound inhabits here: I have a key yet
That commands all: I feare I am metamorphiz'd.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He keepes his fury ſtill, and may doe miſchiefe.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: He ſhalbe hang'd firſt, we'll be ſticklers there, boyes

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: The hundred thouſand Dreams now, that poſſes him
Of jealouſie, and of revenge, and frailtie
Of drawing Bills againſt us, and Petitions.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: And caſting what his credit ſhall recover.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Let him caſt till his Maw come up, we care not.
You ſhall be ſtill ſecured. A great noyſe within.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: We'll pay him home then;
Hark what a noyſe he keeps within?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Certaine
H'as ſet his Chimneys o' fire, or the divell roars there.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: The Codixes o'th' Law are broke looſe, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: He's fighting ſure,

sp.speaker: Di
sp.l: I'll tell ye that immediatly — Exit.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Or doing ſome ſtrange out-rage on himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: Hang him, he dares not be ſo valiant.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: There's no body at home and he chafes like a Lyon,
And ſtinkes withall. Noyſe ſtill.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: No body?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Not a creature,
Nothing within, but he and his Law-tempeſt,
The Ladies, diſhes, kettles, how they fly all?
And how the Glaſſes through the Roomes?

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: My friend ſure
Has got her out and now he has made an end on't.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: See where the Sea comes? how it foams, & bruſſels?
The great Leviathan o'th' Law, how it tumbles?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Made every way an Aſſe? abus'd on all ſides?
And from all quarters, people come to laugh at me?
Riſe like a Comet, to be wonder'd at?
A horrid Comet, for Boyes tongues, and Ballads?
I will run from my wits.

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: Doe, doe, (good Lawyer)
And from thy money too, then thou wilt be quiet.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Here ſhe comes home: now mark the ſalutations;
How like an Aſſe my friend goes?

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: She has pull'd his eares downe.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Now, what ſweet voyage? to what Garden, Lady?
Or to what Coſens houſe?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Is this my welcome?
I cannot goe to Church but thus I am ſcandall'd,
Uſe no devotion for my ſoule, but Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: To Church?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Yes, and ye keep ſweet youths to wait upon me,
Sweet bred-up youths, to be a credit to me.
There's your delight againe, pray take him to ye,
Ho●ever comes neare me more to debaſe me.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: How's this? how's this? good wife, how has he wrongd ye?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I was faine to drive him like a ſheep before me,
I bluſh to thinke how people fleere, and ſcorn'd me,
Others have handſome men, that know behaviour,
Place, and obſervance: this ſilly thing knowes nothing,
Cannot tell ten; Let every Raſcall juſtle me,
And ſtill I puſh'd him on as he had bin comming.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ha! did ye puſh him on? is he ſo ſtupid?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: When others were attentive to the Prieſt,
Good devout Gentleman, then fell he faſt
Faſt, ſound aſleepe: then firſt began the Bag-pipes
The ſeverall ſtops on's noſe, made a rare muſick,
A rare and lowd, and thoſe plaid many an Antheme
Put out of that, he fell ſtrait into dreaming.

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: As cunning, as ſhe is ſweet; I like this carriage.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What did he then?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Why then he talked in his Sleep too,
Nay I'll divulge your morall vertues (ſheeps-face)
And talk'd aloude, that every eare was fixt to him:
Did not I ſuffer (doe you thinke) in this time?
Talk of your bawling Law, of appellations
Of Declarations, and Excommunications:
Warrants, and Executions: and ſuch divells
That drove all the Gentlemen out o'th' Church, by hurryes
With execrable oaths, they would never come there again
Thus am I ſerv'd, and man'd.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I pray ye forgive me,
I muſt confeſſe I am not fit to wait upon ye:
Alas, I was brought up —

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: To be an Aſſe,
A Lawyers Aſſe, to carry Bookes, and Buckrams.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: But what did you at Church?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: At Church, did ye aske her?
Doe you heare gentlemen, doe you mark that queſtion?
Becauſe you are halfe an heretique your ſelfe, Sir,
Would ye breed her too? this ſhall to the Inquiſition,
A pious Gentlewoman, reprov'd for praying?
I'll ſee this filed, and you ſhall heare further, Sir.

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: Ye have an ill heart.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: It ſhall be found out Gentlemen,
There be thoſe youths will ſearch it.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: You are warme Signiour,
But a Faggot will warme ye better: we are witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Enough to hang him, doe not doubt.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Nay certaine,
I doe beleeve has rather no Religion.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: That muſt be knowne too, becauſe ſhee goes to Church, ſir?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Let him goe on, ſir,
His wealth will build a Nunnery, a faire one,
And this good Lady, when he is hang'd, and rotten,
May there be Abbeſſe.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You are cozend, honeſt Gentlemen,
I doe not forbid the uſe, but the forme, marke me.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Forme? what doe ye make of Forme?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They will undoe me,
Sweare, as I oft have done, and ſo betray me;
I muſt make faire way, and hereafter, Wife,
You are welcome home, & henceforth take your pleaſure,
Goe, when ye ſhall thinke fit, I will not hinder ye,
My eyes are open now, and I ſee my errour,
My ſhame as great as that, but I muſt hide it.
The whole conveyance now I ſmell, but Baſta,
Another time muſt ſerve: you ſee us friends, now
Heartily friends and no more chiding (gentlemen)
I have bin too fooliſh, I confeſſe, no more words,
No more (ſweet wife.)

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You know my eaſie nature

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Goe get ye in: you ſee ſhe has bin angry:
Forbeare her ſight a while and time will pacify.
And learne to be more bold.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I would I could,
I will doe all I am able. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Doe Leandro,
We will not part, but friends of all hands.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Well ſaid,
Now ye are reaſonable, we can looke on ye,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ye have ierckt me: but for all that I forgive ye
Forgive ye hartily, and doe invite ye
To morrow to a Breakfaſt, I make but ſeldome
But now we will be merry.

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: Now ye are friendly,
Your doggednes and nigardize flung from ye.
And now we will come to ye

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Give me your hands, all;
You ſhall be wellcome hartily.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: We will be,
For wee'll eate hard

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The harder, the more wellcome,
And till the morning farewell; I have buſines. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Farewell good bountiful Bartolus 'tis a brave wench
A ſudaine witty Theif, and worth all ſervice:
Goe wee'll all goe, and crucifie the Lawyer,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I'll clap foure tire of teeth into my mouth more
But I will grind his ſubſtance.

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: Well Leandro,
Thou haſt had a ſtrange voyage, but I hope
Thou rid'ſt now in ſafe harbour,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Lets goe drinke, Friends,
And laugh alou'd at all our merry may-games

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A match, a match 'twill whet our ſtomachs better.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Madam hees come. Chaire and ſtooles out.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: 'Tis well how did he looke,
When he knew from whom you were ſent? was he not ſtartled?
Or confident? or fearefull?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: As appear'd
Like one that knew his fortune at the worſt,
And car'd not what could follow.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: 'Tis the better
Reach me a Chaire: So bring him in, be carefull
That none diſturb us: I will try his temper,
And if I find him apt for my employments,
I'll worke him to my ends, if not I ſhall
Find other Engines.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Ther's my Ladie,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Leave us

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: You ſent for me?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I did, and do's the favour,
Your preſent ſtate conſidered, and my power,
Deſerve no greater Ceremonie?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Ceremonie?
I uſe to pay that, where I doe owe dutie,
Not to my Brothers wife: I cannot fawne,
If you expect it from me, you are cozen'd,
And ſo farewell.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: He beares up ſtill; I like it,
Pray you a word

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Yes: I will give you hearing
On equall termes, and ſit by you as a friend,
But not ſtand as a Sutour: Now your pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: You are very bold.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: 'Tis fitt: ſince you are proud
I was not made to feed that fooliſh humour,
With flattery and obſervance

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Yet, with your favour,
A little forme ioyn'd with reſpect to her,
That can add to your wants, or free you from 'em
(Nay raiſe you to a fate, beyond your hopes) A Table ready co|vered with Cloath Napkins Salt Trenchers and Bread.
Might well become your wiſedome,

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: It would rather
Write me a Foole, ſhould I but onely think
That any good to me, could flow from you,
Whom for ſo many yeares: I have found and prov'd
My greateſt Enemy: I am ſtill the ſame
My wants have not transform'd me: I dare tell you,
To your new cerviz'd face, what I have ſpoken
Freely behind your back, what I thinke of you,
You are the proudeſt thing, and have the leaſt,
Reaſon to be ſo, that I ever read of
In ſtature you are a Gianteſſe: and your Tailour
Takes meaſure of you, with a Iacobs ſtaffe,
Or he can never reach you, this by the way
For your large ſize: Now, in a word, or two
To treat of your Complexion were decorum:
You are ſo far from faire, I doubt your Mother
Was too familliar with the Moore, that ſerv'd her,
Your Limbes and Features, I paſſe breifely over,
As things not worth deſcription; and come roundly
To your ſoule, if you have any: for 'tis doubtfull

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I laugh at this, proceed

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: This Soule, I ſpeake of
Or rather ſalt to keepe this heape of fleſh,
From being a walking ſtench, like a large Inne,
Stands open for the entertainement of
All impious practiſes: but ther's no Corner
An honeſt thought can take up: and as it were not
Sufficient in your ſelf to comprehend
All wicked plots, you have taught the Foole, my Brother
By your contagion, almoſt to put off
The nature of the man, and turn'd him Devill
Becauſe he ſhould be like you, and I hope
Will march to hell together: I have ſpoken,
And if the limming you, in your true Colours
Can make the Painter gracious, I ſtand readie
For my reward, or if my words diſtaſte you
I weigh it not, for though your Groomes were ready
To cut my throat for't, be aſſur'd I cannot
Uſe other Language

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: You thinke you have ſaid now,
Like a brave fellow: in this Womans War
You ever have bin train'd: ſpoke big: but ſuffer'd
Like a tame Aſſe; and when moſt ſpur'd and gall'd
Were never Maſter of the Spleene or Spirit,
That could raiſe up the anger of a man,
And force it into action,

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Yes vile Creature
Wer't thou a ſubject worthy of my Sword,
Or that thy death, this moment, could call home,
My baniſh'd hopes, thou now wer't dead: dead (woman)
But being as thou art, it is ſufficient
I ſcorne thee, and contemne thee

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: This ſhewes nobly:
I muſt confeſſe it: I am taken with it
For had you kneeld, and whind and ſhew'd a baſe
And low deiected mind, I had deſpis'd you
This Bravery (in your adverſe fortune) conquers
And do's command me, and upon the ſudaine
I feele a kind of pittie, growing in me,
For your misfortunes, pittie ſome ſayes the Parent,
Of future love, and I repent my part,
So far in what you have ſuffered, that I could,
(But you are cold) doe ſomething to repaire
What your baſe Brother (ſuch Iami I thinke him)
Hath brought to ruine

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Be not amaz'd,
Our injuries are equall in his Baſtard
You are familliar with what I grone for
And though the name of Husband holds a tye
Beyond a Brother, I, a poore weake Woman,
Am ſenſible, and tender of a wrong,
And to revenge it, would break through all letts,
That durſt oppoſe me.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: By this kiſſe: ſtart not: thus much, as a ſtranger
You may take from me; But, if you were pleas'd,
I ſhould ſelect you, as a boſome Friend,
I would print 'em, thus, and thus,

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Keepe off.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Come neare,
Neere into the Cabinet of my Counſailes:
Simplicity and patience dwell with Fooles,
And let them beare thoſe burthens, which wiſe men
Boldly ſhake off; Be mine and ioyne with me,
And when that I have rais'd you to a fortune,
(Doe not deny your ſelfe the happie meanes)
You'l looke on me, with more iudicious eies
And ſweare I am moſt faire,

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: What would this Woman?
The purpoſe of theſe words? ſpeake not in ridles
And when I underſtand what you would counſell,
My anſwer ſhall be ſuddaine,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Thus then Iami,
The objects of our fury, are the ſame,
For young Aſcanio, whom you ſnake like hug'd
(Frozen with wants to death) in your warme boſome,
Lives to ſupplant you in your certaine hopes,
And kills in me all comfort.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Now 'tis plaine,
I apprehend you: and were he remov'd —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: You, once againe were the undoubted heire.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: 'Tis not to be denyed; I was ice before,
But now ye have fir'd me, —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I'l add fuell to it,
And by a nearer cut, doe you but ſteere
As I direct you bring our Bark into
The Port of happines,

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: By Henriques death:
But you'l ſay hee's your Brother; in great fortunes
(Which are epitomes of States & Kingdomes) Diſhes cove|red with pa|pers in each ready.
The po●iticke brooke no Rivalls.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Excellent.
For ſure I thinke out of a ſcrupulous feare,
To feed in expectation when I may
(Diſpenſing but a little with my conſcience)
Come into full poſſeſſion, would not argue
One that deſir'd to thrive,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Now you ſpeake like
A man that knowes the World.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: I needs muſt learne
That have ſo good a Tutreſſe: And what thinke you,
(Don Henrique and Aſcanio cut off)
That none may live, that ſhall deſire to trace us
In our black pathes, if that Octavio
His foſter Father' and the ſad Iacinta,
(Faith pittie her, and free her from her Sorrowes)
Should fall Companions with 'em? When we are red
With murther, let us often bath in blood,
The collour will be ſcarlet.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: And that's glorious,
And will protect the fact

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Suppoſe this don:
(If undiſcovered) we may get for money,
(As that you know buyes any thing in Rome)
A diſpenſation

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: And be married?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: True.
Or if it be knowne, truſſe up our Gold and Jewells,
And fly to ſome free State, and there with ſcorne —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Laugh at the lawes of Spaine.
'Twere admirable.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: We ſhall beget rare Children. I am rap'd with
The meere imagination —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Shall it be don?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Shall? tis too tedious: furniſh me with meanes
To hire the inſtruments, and to your ſelf,
Say it is done already: I will ſhew you,
'Ere the Sun ſet, how much you have wrought upon me,
Your province is onely to uſe ſome meanes,
To ſend my Brother, to the Grove that's neighbour,
To the weſt Port of th' Citie; leave the reſt,
To my owne practiſe; I have talk'd too long:
But now will doe: this kiſſe, with my Confeſſion,
To worke a fell revenge: A mans a foole,
If not inſtructed in a Womans Schoole. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Bartolus Algazeirs and a Paratour. The Table ſet out and ſtooles.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You are well enough diſguiz'd, furniſh the Table,
Make no ſhew, what ye are, till I diſcover
Not a ſoule knowes ye here: be quick and dilligent,
Theſe youthes, I have invited to a Breakefaſt,
But what the Sawce will be, I am of opinion
I ſhall take off the edges of their Appetites,
And greaze their gums, for eating hartily;
This month or two they have plaid their prizes with me
And with their ſeverall flurts they have lighted dangerouſly
But ſure I ſhall be quit: I heare 'em comming
Goe off, and wait the bringing in your ſervice,
And doe it handſomely: you know where to have it
Wellcome i'Faith,

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: That's well ſaid, honeſt Lawyer,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Said like a Neighbour

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Wellcome all: all over
And let's be merry:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: To that end we came Sir,
An hower of freedome's worth an age of juglings,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I am come too Sir, to ſpecifie my Stomach
A poore reteyner to your worſhips bountie,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And thou ſhalt have it fill'd, my merry Diego,
My liberall, and my bonney bounteous Diego
Even fil●d till it groane againe

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Let it have faire play,
And if it founder then—
I'll tell ye neighbours,
Though I were angry yeſterday, with ye all,
And very angry for me thought ye bobd me.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: No, no, by no meanes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, when I conſidered
It was a jeſt, and carried off ſo quaintly
It made me merry: very merry, Gentlemen,
I doe confes I could not ſleepe to thinke on't
The mirth ſo tickled me, I could not ſlumber,

sp.speaker: Lop,
sp.l: Good mirth do's worke ſo: honeſt mirth,
Now, ſhould we have meant in earneſt—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You ſay true Neighbour,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: It might have bred ſuch a diſtaſt and ſowreneſſe,
Such fond imaginations in your Braines, Sir
For things thruſt home in earneſt —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Very certaine
But I know ye all for merry waggs, and ere long
You ſhall know me too. in another faſhion
Though y'are pamper d ye ſhall beare part 'oth burthen.
Come Wife; Come bid 'em wellcome; Come my Jewell:
And Pupill, you ſhall come too; nere hang backward,
Come, come the womans pleas'd, her angers over,
Come, be not baſhfull,

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What do's he prepare here?
Sure ther's no meate 'ith houſe at leaſt none dreſt,
Do's he meane to mock 'em? or ſome new bred Crotchet
Come o're his braines; I doe not like his kindnes?
But ſilence beſt becomes me: if he meane foule play
Sure they are enough to right themſelves and let 'em,
I'll ſit by, ſo they beat him not to powder,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Bring in the meate there, ha? Sit downe deare Neighbour
A little meate needs little Complement,
Sit downe I ſay:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What doe you meane by this Sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Convay away their weapons handſomely,

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You know ther's none ith' houſe to anſwer ye,
But the poore Girle; you know ther's no meat neither

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Peace and be quiet; I ſhall make you ſmoak els
Ther's men and Meate enough, ſet it downe formally

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I feare ſome lew'd tricke, yet I dare not ſpeake on't

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I have no dainties for ye Gentlemen,
Nor ●odes of meat, to make the roome ſmell of'em
Onely a diſh to every man I have dedicated,
And if I have pleas'd his appetite,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: O, a Capon,
A Bird of grace, and be thy will, I honour it

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: For me ſome fortie pound of lovely Beeffe,
Plac'd in a mediterranean ſea of Brewiſſe

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Fall to, fall to that we may drinke and laugh after
Wait diligently knaves,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: What rare bits this?
An execution, bleſſe me!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Nay take it to ye
Ther's no avoiding it 'tis ſomewhat tough Sir,
But a good ſtomach will endure it eaſely
The ſum is, but a thouſand duckets Sir,

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: A Capias from my Surgeon, and my Silke man,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Your carefull makers, but they have mard your diet
Stir not, your Swords are gon: ther's no avoiding me
And theſe are Algazeirs, doe you heare that paſſing bell?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A ſtrong Citation, bleſſe me!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Out with your Beads, Curat,
The devills in your diſh: bell, booke, and Candell,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A warrant to appeare before the Judges?
I muſt needs riſe, and turne to'th wall.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ye need not,
Your feare I hope will make ye find your Breeches,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are betraid

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Invited, doe not wrong me,
Fall to, good Gueſts, you have dilligent men about ye,
Ye ſhall want nothing, that may perſecute ye
Theſe will not ſee ye ſtart; Have I now found ye
Have I requited ye? You fool d the Lawyer,
And thought it meritorious, to abuſe him,
A thick ram headed knave: you rid, you ſpurd him,
And glorified your witts, the more ye wrongd him;
Within this hower, ye ſhall have all your Creditours,
A ſecond diſh of new debts, come upon ye,
And new invitements to the whip (Don Diego)
And Excommunications for the Learned Curat,
A Maſque of all your furies ſhall dance to ye,

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: You dare not uſe us thus?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You ſhall be bobd (Gentlemen)
Stir, and as I have a life, ye goe to priſon
To priſon, without pittie inſtantly
Before ye ſpeake another word to priſon.
I have a better Guard, without, that waytes;
Doe you ſee this man, Don Curat? 'tis a Paratour
That comes to tell ye a delightfull ſtory.
Of an old whore, ye have and then to teach ye
What is the penaltie; Laugh at me now Sir,
What Legacie would ye bequeath me now,
(And pay it on the naile?) to fly my fury?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: O gentle Sir,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do'ſt thou hope I will be gentle,
Thou fooliſh unconſiderate Curat?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Let me goe Sir,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'll ſee thee hang firſt.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: And as I am a true Vicar,
Hark in your eare, hark ſoftly —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, no bribery.
I'll have my ſwindge upon thee; Sirha? Raſcall?
You lenten Chaps, you that lay ſick, and mockt me,
Mockt me, abhominably; abuſed me lewdly
I'll make thee ſick at heart, before I leave thee,
And groane, and dye indeed, and be worth nothing
Not worth a bleſſing, nor a Bell to knell for thee,
A ſheete to cover thee, but that thou ſtealeſt,
Stealeſt from the Merchant, and the Ring he was buried with
Stealeſt from his Grave, doe you ſmell me now?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Have mercy on me!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No Pſalme of mercy ſhall hold me from hanging thee
How do ye like your Breakfaſt? 'tis but ſhort, Gentlemen
But ſweet and healthfull; Your puniſhment, and yours, Sir
For ſome neare reaſons, that concernes my Credit,
I will take to my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Doe Sir, and ſpare not
I have bin too good a wife, and too obedient,
But ſince ye dare provoke me to be fooliſh —

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: She has, yes, and too worthie of your uſage,
Before the world, I juſtifie her goodnes,
And turne that man, that dares but taint her vertues,
To my Swords point; that lying man, that baſe man,
Turne him, but face to face, that I may know him

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What have I here?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: A Gentleman, a free man,
One that made triall of this Ladies conſtancie,
And found it ſtrong as fate; Leave off your fooling,
For if you follow this courſe, you will be Chronicled
For a devill, whilſt a Saint ſhe is mentioned,
You know my name indeed; I am now no Lawyer.
Some comfort now, I hope, or els would I wer hanged up

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: And yet the Judge, he makes me ſwet.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What newes now?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: I will juſtifie upon my life, and Credit
What you have heard, for truth, and will make prooffe of

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: I will be ready at the appointed hower there,
And ſo I leave ye.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Stay I beſeech your worſhip,
And doe but heare me,

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Good Sir, intend this buſines,
And let this bawling Foole; No more words Lawyer,
And no more angers, for I gueſſe your reaſons,
This Gentleman, i'l juſtifie in all places,
And that faire Ladies worth; Let who dare croſſe it,
The Plot was caſt by me, to make thee jealous,
But not to wrong your wife, ſhe is faire and vertuous,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Take us to mercy too, we beſeech your honour,
We ſhall be juſtified the way of all fleſh els,

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: No more talke, nor no more diſſention Lawyer,
I know your anger, 'tis a vaine and ſlight one,
For if you doe; i'll lay your whole life open
A life that all the world ſhall i'll bring witnes,
And rip before a Judge the ulcerous villanies
You know I know ye, and I can bring witnes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Nay good Sir, noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Be at peace then preſently,
Immediately take honeſt and faire truce
With your good Wife, and ſhake hands with that Gentleman;
Has honour'd ye too much, and doe it cheerefully,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Take us along, for heaven ſake too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am Friends,
There is no remedie, I muſt put up all,
And like my neighbours rub it ou't by'th ſhoulders,
And perfect friends; Leandro now I thanke ye,
And ther's my hand, I have no more grudge to ye,
But I am too meane henceforward for your Companie,

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I ſhall not trouble ye,

sp.speaker: Arſ.
sp.l: We will be friends too:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Nay Lawyer, you ſhall not fright us farther,
For all your devills wee will bolt,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I grant ye.
The Gentlemans your Baile and thank his comming,
Did not he know me too well, you ſhould ſmart for't;
Goe all in peace, but when ye Foole next, Gentlemen,
Come not to me to Breakefaſt.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I'l be bak'd firſt.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And pray ye remember, when ye are bold & merry,
The Lawyers Bancket, and the Sawce he gave ye,

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Come: goe along; I have employment for ye,
Employment for your lewd braynes too, to coole ye.
For all, for every one.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are all your Servants.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: All, all for any thing, from this day forward,
I'l hate all Breakefaſts, and depend on dinners

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: I am glad you come off faire

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: The faire has bleſt me.

div.head: Scena Tertia.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: This is the place, but why we are appointed
By Don Iami to ſtay here, is a depth
I cannot ſound,

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: Beleev't he is too noble,
To purpoſe any thing but for our good
Had I aſſurance of a thouſand Lives,
And with them perpetuitie of pleaſure,
And ſhould looſe all, if he prov'd only falſe,
Yet I durſt run the hazard,

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: 'Tis our comfort,
We cannot be more wretched then we are,
And death concludes all miſery,

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Undiſcovered
We muſt attend him

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: Our ſtay is not long
With him Don Henrique?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Now I feare;
Be ſilent.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Why do'ſt thou follow me?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: To ſave your life,
A plot is laid for't, all my wrongs forgot,
I have a Brothers Love,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: But thy falſe ſelf,
I feare no enemy.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: You have no Friend,
But what breathes in me: If you move a ſtep
Beyond this ground you tread on: you are loſt.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: 'Tis by thy practiſe then: I am ſent hither
To meete her, that prefers my life, and ſafetie
Before her owne.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: That you ſhould be abus'd thus
With weake credulitie: She for whoſe ſake,
You have forgot we had one noble Father,
Or that one Mother bare us, for whoſe love,
You breake a contract, to which heaven was witnes,
To ſatisfie whoſe pride, and willfull humour,
You have expos'd a ſweet, and hopefull Son,
To all the miſeries, that want can bring him,
And ſuch a Son, though you are moſt obdurate,
To give whom entertainement Savages
Would quit their Caves themſelves, to keepe him from
Bleake cold, and hunger: This diſſembling Woman,
This Idoll, whom you worſhip: all your love
And ſervice trod under her feete, deſignes you
To fill a grave or dead, to lye a pray,
For Wolues, and vultures.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: 'Tis falſe; I defie thee,
And ſtand upon my Guard

div.stage: Enter Leandro Millanes, Arſenio, Bart. Lopez, Deigo, Octavio Iacinta Aſcanio and Servants.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Alas, 'tis weake:
Come on, ſince you will teach me to be cruell,
By having no faith, in me, take your fortune,
Bring the reſt forth, and bind them faſt.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: In what have we offended?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: I am deafe,
And following my will, I doe not ſtand
Accomptable to reaſon: See her Ring
(The firſt pledge of your love, and ſervice to her)
Deliverd as a Warrant for your death:
Theſe Bags of gold you gave up to her truſt,
(The uſe of which, you did deny your ſelfe)
Beſtow'd on me, and with a prodigall hand,
Whom ſhe pick'd forth to be the Architect
Of her moſt bloudy building; and to Fee
Theſe Inſtruments, to bring Materials
To raiſe it up, ſhe bad me ſpare no coſt,
And (as a ſurpluſage) offer'd her ſelfe
To be at my devotion.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: O accurſs'd!

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: But be incredulous ſtill; think this my plot;
Faſhion excuſes to your ſelfe, and ſweare
That ſhe is innocent, that ſhe doats on ye;
Believe this, as a fearefull Dreame, and that
You Ile not at my mercy, which in this
I will ſhew onely: She her ſelfe ſhall give
The dreadfull Sentence, to remove all ſcruple
Who 'tis that ſends you to the other world.
Appeares my Violante? ſpeake (my deareſt)
Do's not the object pleaſe you?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: More then if
All Treaſure that's above the earth, with that,
That lyes conceal'd in both the Indian Mines,
Were laid downe at my feet: O bold Iamy
Thou onely canſt deſerve me.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: I am forward,
And (as you eaſily may perceive,) I ſleepe not
On your commands.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But yet they live: I look'd
To find them dead.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: That was defer'd, that you
Might triumph in their miſery, and have the powre
To ſay they are not,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: 'Twas well thought upon:
This kiſſe, and all the pleaſures of my Bed
This night, ſhall thanke thee.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Monſter!

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: You Sir, that
Would have me mother Baſtards, being unable
To honour me with one Child of mine owne,
That underneath my Roofe, kept your caſt-Strumpet,
And out of my Revenues, would maintaine
Her riotous iſſue: Now you find what 'tis
To tempt a woman: with as little feeling
As I turne off a ſlave, that is unfit
To doe me ſervice; or a horſe, or dog
That have out-liv'd their uſe, I ſhake thee off,
To make thy peace with heaven.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I doe deſerve this,
And never truly felt before, what ſorrow
Attends on wilfull dotage.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: For you, Miſtris,
That had the pleaſure of his youth before me,
And triumph'd in the fruit, that you had by him,
But that I thinke, to have the Baſtard ſtrangled
Before thy face, and thou with ſpeed to follow
The way he leades thee, is ſufficient torture,
I would cut off thy noſe, put out thine eyes,
And ſet my foot on theſe bewitching lips,
That had the ſtart of mine: but as thou art,
Goe to the grave unpittied.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: Who would beleeve
Such rage could be in woman?

sp.speaker: Ʋiol,
sp.l: For this Fellow,
He is not worth my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Let him live then,
Since you eſteeme him innocent.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: No, Iamy,
He ſhall make up the meſſe: now ſtrike together
And let them fall ſo.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: Unheard of crueltie
I can endure no longer: ſeize on her.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.l: Am I betraid?
Is this thy faith, Iamy?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Could your deſires
Challenge performance of a deed ſo horrid?
Or, though that you had ſold your ſelfe to hell,
I ſhould make up the bargaine? Live (deare Brother)
Live long, and happy: I forgive you freely;
To have done you this ſervice, is to me
A faire Inheritance: And how e're harſh language
(Call'd on, by your rough uſage) paſs'd my lipps,
In my heart, I ever lov'd you: All my labours
Were but to ſhew, how much your love was cozen'd,
When it beheld it ſelfe in this falſe Glaſſe,
That did abuſe you; and I am ſo far
From envying young Aſcanio his good fortune,
That if your State were mine, I would adopt him.
Theſe are the Murtherers my noble Friends,
Which (to make triall of her bloudy purpoſe)
I won, to come diſguis'd thus.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I am too full
Of griefe, and ſhame to ſpeake: but what I'le doe,
Shall to the world proclaime my penitence;
And howſoever I have liv'd, I'le die
A much chang'd man.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Were it but poſſible
You could make ſatisfaction to this woman,
Our joyes were perfect.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: That's my onely comfort,
That it is in my power: I ne're was married
To this bad woman, though I doted on her,
But daily did deferre it ſtill expecting
When griefe would kill Iacintha.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: All is come out,
And finds a faire ſucceſſe: take her Don Henrique,
And once againe embrace your Son.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Moſt gladly.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: Your Brother hath deſerv'd well.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: And ſhall ſhare
The moitie of my State,

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: I have heard, Advocate,
What an ill Inſtrument you have bin to him,
From this time ſtrengthen him, with honeſt counſells,
As you'le deſerve my pardon.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'le change my Copy:
But I am puniſh'd, for I feare I have had
A ſmart blow, though unſeene.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: Curat, and Sexton,
I have heard of you too, let me heare no more,
And what's paſt, is forgotten; For this woman,
Though her intent were bloody, yet our Law
Calls it not death: yet that her puniſhment
May deter others from ſuch bad attempts,
The Dowry ſhe brought with her ſhall be emploi'd
To build a Nunnery, where ſhe ſhall ſpend
The remnant of her life.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Since I have miſs'd my ends,
I ſcorne what can fall on me.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: The ſtrict diſcipline
Of the Church, will teach you better thoughts. And Signiors.
You that are Batchelours, if you ever marry,
In Bartolus, you may behold the iſſue
Of Covetouſneſſe, and Jealouſie; And of dotage,
And falſhood in Don Henrique keep a meane then;

l.hi: For be aſſur'd that weake man meets all ill,
That gives himſelfe up to a womans will.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: TO tell ye (Gentlemen,) we have a Play,
A new one too, and that 'tis launch'd to day,
The Name ye know, that's nothing to my Story;
To tell ye, 'tis familiar, void of Glory;
Of State, of Bitterneſſe: of wit you'll ſay,
For that is now held wit, that tends that way,
Which we avoid: To tell ye to 'tis merry,
And meant to make ye pleaſant, and not weary:
The Streame that guides ye, eaſie to attend:
To tell ye that 'tis good, is to no end,
If you believe not. Nay, to goe thus far,
To ſweare it, if you ſweare againſt, is war
To aſſure you any thing, unleſse you ſee,
And ſo conceive, is vanity in me;
Therefore I leave it to it ſelfe, and pray
Like a good Barke, it may worke out to day,
And ſtem all doubts; 'twas built for ſuch a proofe,
And we hope highly: if ſhe lye aloofe
For her owne vantage, to give wind at will,
Why let her worke, onely be you but ſtill,
And ſweet opinion'd, and we are bound to ſay,
You are worthy Judges, and you crowne the Play.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: THe Play is done, yet our Suit never ends,
Still when you part, you would ſtil part our friends,
Our nobleſt friends; if ought have falne amis,
O let it be ſufficient, that it is,
And you have pardon'd it. In Buildings great
All the whole Body, cannot be ſo neat,
But ſomething may be mended; Thoſe are faire,
And worthy love, that may deſtroy, but ſpare.
